questions.text: The JALMA Institute for Leprosy and Other Mycobacterial Diseases is located in which city?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The JALMA Institute for Leprosy and Other Mycobacterial Diseases, commonly known as JALMA, is located in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India.

It is one of the premier institutions in the country dedicated to research, treatment, and control of leprosy and other mycobacterial diseases.

High prevalence of cases in childhood indicates the disease is active and spreading
Bacterial load is high in the tuberculoid variety
It may be transmitted by insect vectors

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the epidemiology of leprosy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In leprosy, bacterial load is typically low in the tuberculoid variety and high in the lepromatous variety.
  • The tuberculoid variety is characterised by a localised, cell-mediated immune response, resulting in few or no bacteria within the lesions.
  • On the other hand, the lepromatous variety is associated with a high bacterial load and widespread dissemination of the bacteria throughout the body.

Explanation of other options:

Low prevalence of cases in childhood indicates the disease is inactive and not spreading (Option A), High prevalence of cases in childhood indicates the disease is active and spreading (Option B): Leprosy primarily affects individuals in childhood or adolescence, and a high prevalence of cases in this age group can indicate ongoing transmission of the disease within the community. Children are more susceptible to leprosy due to their immature immune systems and increased likelihood of close contact with infected individuals, such as family members.

It may be transmitted by insect vectors (Option D): Leprosy is primarily transmitted through prolonged close contact with untreated individuals who have the active form of the disease. However, the bacilli may also be transmitted by insect vectors such as armadillos and certain species of mosquitoes or by tattooing needles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with suspected leprosy is given an intradermal injection of lepromin to assess his cell-mediated immunity for disease classification. The delayed reaction, used to evaluate long-term immune response, should be read at which time point?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The delayed reaction refers to the Mitsuda reaction seen following the intradermal lepromin skin test used to evaluate the immune status of leprosy patients. It is read on the 21st day after antigen injection.

Lepromin test:

The test is performed by injecting intradermally 0.1 ml of lepromin into the inner aspect of the forearm of the individual. As a routine, the reaction is read at 48 hours and 21 days. Two types of positive reactions have been described:

Early reaction:

  • The early reaction is also known as the Fernandez reaction.
  • An inflammatory response appears within 24 to 48 hours after lepromin injection and fades by 3 to 4 days.
  • It presents as redness and induration, and a diameter >10 mm at 48 hours is considered positive.
  • The early positive reaction indicates whether or not a person has been previously sensitised by exposure to and infection by the leprosy bacilli.
  • It represents a delayed hypersensitivity response to soluble bacillary antigens, similar to the Mantoux reaction in tuberculosis.

Late reaction:

  • This is the classical Mitsuda reaction.
  • The reaction develops late, and the test is read at 21 days.
  • At the end of 21 days, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter at the site of inoculation, the reaction is said to be positive.
  • The Lepromin test has been generally accepted as a useful tool in evaluating the immune status (cell-mediated immunity) of leprosy patients. It is also of great value in estimating the prognosis in cases of leprosy of all types.
  • The test is usually strongly positive in the typical tuberculoid cases, and the positivity gets weaker as one passes through the spectrum to the lepromatous end, the typical lepromatous cases being lepromin negative, indicating a failure of CMI.

questions.text: In India, elimination of leprosy is defined as achieving a prevalence rate of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India defines elimination of leprosy as achieving a prevalence rate of less than 1 case per 10,000 population.
  • This criterion signifies a very low level of transmission and indicates that leprosy is no longer a public health problem requiring specific intervention measures.

National Leprosy Eradication Programme:

  • The National Leprosy Control Programme (NLCP) has been in operation since 1955, a centrally aided programme to achieve control of leprosy through early detection of cases and DDS (dapsone) monotherapy on an ambulatory basis.
  • The components of the programme are as follows :
    • Decentralised integrated leprosy services through the general health care system;
    • Capacity building of all general health services functionaries;
    • Intensified information, education and communication;
    • Prevention of disability and medical rehabilitation; and
    • Intensified monitoring and supervision.

choices.text: Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva
Vascular pannus at the superior limbus

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic criteria is better regarded as a convenient index of trachomatous inflammation for epidemiological studies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trachomatous inflammation is a key clinical feature used to assess the prevalence and severity of trachoma, an infectious eye disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Trachoma is a major preventable cause of blindness in developing countries.
  • Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, known as tarsal conjunctival follicles, are a characteristic sign of active trachomatous inflammation.
  • These follicles represent inflammatory responses to Chlamydia infection and are considered the most convenient index for assessing the presence of trachomatous inflammation in epidemiological studies.
  • They are relatively easy to identify during clinical examinations and are commonly used as a primary diagnostic criterion for grading the severity of trachoma.
  • Thus, in epidemiological studies, more stress is now put on the upper tarsal conjunctiva as a convenient index of trachomatous inflammation in the eye as a whole. But, for diagnosis in the field, cases must have at least 2 of the following diagnostic criteria:
    • Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva
    • Limbal follicles or their sequelae, Herbert's pits
    • Typical conjunctival scarring (trichiasis, entropion)
    • Vascular pannus, most marked at the superior limbus

choices.text: Morax-Axenfeld bacillus is the most widespread
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most dangerous co-infecting organism in trachoma
Koch-Weeks bacillus is the most innocuous
Chlamydia trachomatis serotype D is the main cause of blinding sequelae in trachoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathogenic organisms of trachoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a highly virulent bacterium known to cause gonorrhoea, a sexually transmitted infection.
  • In trachoma, Neisseria gonorrhoeae can contribute to severe ocular inflammation and corneal damage, leading to blindness.
  • While Chlamydia trachomatis is the primary pathogen associated with trachoma, secondary bacterial infections, including gonococcal infection, can exacerbate the disease process and increase the risk of complications.

Causative Agents of Trachoma:

  • The classical endemic trachoma of developing countries is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis of immune types A, B, or C.
  • The serotypes A, B, and C causing trachoma lead to blindness, which is irreversible and preventable.
  • The sexually-transmitted C. trachomatis serotypes D, E, F, G, H, I, J or K may also infect, causing an eye disease difficult to differentiate from endemic trachoma.
  • Milder cases of this are usually called inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • These strains rarely produce permanent vision loss, but they cause pneumonia in infants and genital tract infections in adults.
  • Other pathogenic organisms like Morax-Axenfeld diplobacillus, the Koch-Weeks bacillus, and the gonococcus often contribute to the disease process.

Explanation of other options:

Morax-Axenfeld bacillus is the most prevalent (Option A): While Moraxella catarrhalis (formerly known as Morax-Axenfeld bacillus) can be associated with bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not considered the primary pathogen responsible for trachoma. Trachoma is primarily caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and is transmitted through direct contact with infected ocular or nasal secretions.

Koch-Weeks bacillus is the most innocuous (Option C): The Koch-Weeks bacillus (Haemophilus aegyptius) is one of the most frequent causes of conjunctivitis. Koch-Weeks bacillus can sometimes infect eyes already damaged by trachoma as a secondary invader. It is commonly regarded as a more or less benign organism, producing a self-limited contagious inflammation of the conjunctiva.

Chlamydia trachomatis serotype D is the main cause of blinding sequelae in trachoma (Option D): Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B, and C, causing trachoma, lead to blindness, while serotype D typically causes inclusion conjunctivitis and rarely results in permanent vision loss.

questions.text: The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The World Health Organisation (WHO) defines the elimination of neonatal tetanus as achieving less than one case of neonatal tetanus per 1000 live births in every district of a country.
  • This threshold signifies a very low incidence of neonatal tetanus and indicates effective immunisation coverage and clean delivery practices.
  • Achieving this target requires a combination of strategies, including immunising pregnant women with tetanus toxoid vaccine, promoting clean delivery practices, and ensuring access to skilled birth attendants.

questions.text: Which disease is commonly referred to as the "eighth day disease"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tetanus neonatorum, also known as neonatal tetanus, is commonly referred to as the eighth-day disease because symptoms typically appear around the eighth day of life in infants born under unhygienic conditions.
  • It is a severe form of tetanus that occurs in newborns caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which enters the body through contaminated umbilical cord care practices, particularly in unhygienic childbirth environments.
  • The umbilical stump is often the entry point for the bacteria, and symptoms can include muscle stiffness, difficulty feeding, and spasms.

Explanation of other options:

Yaws (Option A): Yaws is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue. It primarily affects the skin, bones, and cartilage, causing lesions and ulcers. Yaws is not commonly referred to as the eighth-day disease. It typically presents with skin lesions that develop over weeks to months, rather than within the first days of life.

Endemic syphilis (Option B): Endemic syphilis, also known as non-venereal syphilis or bejel, is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies endemicum. It primarily affects the skin, mucous membranes, and bones. Endemic syphilis can affect individuals of all ages. Its clinical presentation does not typically align with symptoms appearing within the first days of life.

Pinta (Option D): Pinta is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Treponema carateum. It primarily affects the skin, causing hypo-pigmented or hyper-pigmented patches. Its clinical presentation also does not typically involve symptoms appearing within the first days of life.

questions.text: The One World One Health strategy primarily focuses on the prevention and control of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The One World, One Health (OWOH) strategy is a holistic approach to public health that recognises the interconnections between human health, animal health, and the environment.
  • It is particularly relevant to the prevention and control of zoonotic diseases such as H1N1 influenza, also known as swine flu.
  • H1N1 influenza is a zoonotic disease originating from pigs that can infect humans and spread rapidly.
  • Because of this animal-human transmission, preventing and controlling H1N1 requires coordinated efforts across human health, veterinary health, and environmental sectors, which is the core idea of OWOH.
  • Bird flu (avian influenza) was another of the prime forces behind the movement of One Health.
  • The One World, One Health strategy emphasises collaboration and coordination across various sectors, including human health, veterinary health, agriculture, environmental health, and wildlife conservation, to address health threats that transcend species boundaries.
  • Diabetes, accidents, and AIDS are primarily human health issues without direct animal or environmental transmission links, so they fall outside the main scope of the One Health approach.

questions.text: Soil serves as a natural reservoir for all of the following organisms except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brucellosis is caused by Brucella species, with main reservoirs in animals like cattle, sheep, goats, swine, buffaloes, horses, and dogs.
  • Humans primarily acquire brucellosis through direct contact with infected animals or by consuming unpasteurized dairy products, not from soil, which is not a typical reservoir.
  • Soil is the reservoir for pathogens that cause tetanus, anthrax, coccidioidomycosis and mycetoma.

Explanation of other options :

Coccidioidomycosis (Option A): Coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley fever, is a fungal infection caused by inhaling spores of the fungus Coccidioides, which typically resides in the soil in certain regions. When soil containing Coccidioides spores is disturbed, such as during construction or agricultural activities, the spores can become airborne and potentially infect humans and animals.

Anthrax (Option B): Anthrax is a bacterial infection caused by Bacillus anthracis. The spores of this bacterium can persist in the soil for years and are typically deposited there by infected animals. Humans can become infected with anthrax by coming into contact with contaminated soil, animal products, or by inhaling spores. Soil serves as a reservoir for anthrax spores, contributing to the persistence of the disease in certain regions.

Tetanus (Option D): Tetanus, also known as lockjaw, is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is commonly found in soil, dust, and animal faeces. The bacteria produce spores that can survive in the environment for long periods. Tetanus typically enters the body through cuts or wounds contaminated with soil, allowing the spores to germinate and produce toxins that affect the nervous system.

questions.text: A patient with a recent history of travel to Africa presents with jaundice, hemorrhagic fever, and conjunctival effusion. Despite treatment, he succumbed to the illness. Which of the following vaccines could have potentially prevented his death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation, along with recent travel to Africa, suggests yellow fever and yellow fever is preventable by the 17D vaccine.

  • Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by an arbovirus.
  • The disease is endemic to tropical America and Africa.
  • The reservoir of infection is vertebrates, mainly monkeys and is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of infected mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti.
  • Severe cases of yellow fever present with jaundice, hemorrhagic manifestations, shock and even coma.
  • Vaccination with the 17 D vaccine is the most effective preventive measure against yellow fever.

17D vaccine:

  • The 17 D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine against yellow fever.
  • It provides effective and long-lasting immunity against the yellow fever virus infection and is recommended for individuals travelling to or residing in areas where yellow fever is endemic.
  • A traveller without a valid international certificate of vaccination for yellow fever will be placed in quarantine for 6 days (Maximum incubation period).
  • Validity of vaccination certificate begins 10 days after vaccination and extends lifelong.

Explanation of other options:

Nakayama strain vaccine (Option B): This refers to the Inactivated Mouse Brain-Derived vaccine of Japanese encephalitis. This vaccine is available in India and is an integral part of the Universal Immunisation Programme in endemic districts like UP, Assam, West Bengal and Karnataka.

Ra 27/3 strain vaccine (Option C): The Ra 27/3 strain vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine against rubella. While the rubella vaccine is important for preventing rubella infection and its complications, it is not effective against yellow fever.

Jeryl Lynn strain vaccine (Option D): The Jeryl Lynn strain is the live attenuated strain used in the mumps vaccine, commonly included in the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine. It protects against the mumps virus, which causes swelling of the salivary glands and other complications.

questions.text: A patient reports loss of sensation to cold, heat, touch, and pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely diagnosis for a patient reporting loss of sensations to cold, hot, touch, and pain stimuli is Leprosy.

  • Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae.
  • It primarily affects the skin and peripheral nerves, leading to various neurological manifestations.
  • Leprosy primarily affects the peripheral nerves, resulting in sensory loss, particularly in the extremities.
  • Patients with leprosy may experience hypoesthesia or anaesthesia, meaning reduced or absent sensation, to various stimuli, including cold, hot, touch, and pain.
  • Additionally, leprosy can cause skin lesions, nerve thickening, and deformities.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Tuberculosis primarily affects the lungs but can also involve other organs. While extrapulmonary tuberculosis can affect the peripheral nerves, it typically presents with symptoms such as cough, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Loss of sensation to cold, hot, touch, and pain stimuli is not a characteristic symptom of tuberculosis.

Herpes zoster (Option C): Herpes zoster is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus in a dorsal root ganglion. It results in painful, vesicular rash and sensory symptoms in a specific dermatome. It causes acute nerve pain but not widespread loss of sensation to all modalities.

Syphilis (Option D): Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, can affect the nervous system in its tertiary stage, called neurosyphilis. It may cause sensory deficits, but it is primarily due to the involvement of the posterior columns, leading to loss of proprioception and vibration sense, rather than loss of pain and temperature sensation.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria qualify an individual for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) after contact with a leprosy patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae.
  • It primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, mucosal surfaces of the upper respiratory tract, and the eyes.
  • Close contacts of individuals with leprosy are at increased risk of acquiring the infection.
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for leprosy contacts aims to prevent leprosy transmission among high-risk contacts.
  • PEP is provided under the National Leprosy Eradication Program, but only to select contacts based on specific criteria. This includes:
    • Contacts who have had more than three months of exposure, especially household members in close contact (over 20 hours per week) with a newly diagnosed infectious leprosy case within the past year.
    • Contacts aged above 2 years
  • The PEP regimen consists of a single dose of rifampicin. Dosage for single-dose rifampicin is:
    • Over 35 kg: 600 mg
    • 20 to 35 kg: 450 mg
    • Under 20 kg: 10-15 mg/kg body weight

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a single hypopigmented, hypoesthetic skin patch and a thickened peripheral nerve. The image shows two WHO multidrug therapy blister packs labelled A and B. Which is the most appropriate regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a single hypopigmented, hypoesthetic plaque and a thickened peripheral nerve, which is highly suggestive of paucibacillary (PB) leprosy (single lesion).
  • In the image, Pack A (green) contains the PB regimen - Rifampicin 600 mg once monthly (supervised) and Dapsone 100 mg daily (self-administered).
  • PB leprosy is treated with Pack A for 6 months according to WHO MDT guidelines.

Leprosy treatment:

  • In India, WHO-recommended multidrug therapy (MDT) is followed for leprosy.
  • Both paucibacillary (PB) and multibacillary (MB) cases are treated with a three-drug regimen of:
    • Rifampicin
    • Dapsone
    • Clofazimine
  • Duration of treatment:
    • Paucibacillary: 6 months (Image A)
    • Multibacillary: 12 months (Image B)

Key Takeaways:
